title: Gabriel Jesus' scoring record proves brilliant Brazilian is Manchester City's heir to Sergio Aguero
text:
Gabriel Jesus is scoring a goal every 108 minutes since the start of last season. There are only seven men in Europe with a deadlier record. One, it so happens, is Sergio Aguero.

Dislodging Manchester City’s greatest ever goalscorer is an unenviable task and it is fair to say that at times last year Jesus was questioning whether it was all worth it. Although only 22, he would lead the line for the majority of Europe’s elite, as he does for Brazil, ahead of Roberto Firmino.

Other than Aguero, only Messrs Messi, Mbappe, Lewandowski, Neymar, Cavani and Alcacer score at a quicker rate than Jesus. Three play for one runaway club in France.

Gabriel Jesus (right) celebrated after giving Manchester City the lead at Crystal Palace

Another is perhaps the greatest player who has ever lived. Saturday’s goal — a header off his shoulder, manufactured by the swan dive to meet Bernardo Silva’s teasing cross — meant he has now scored in each of his last seven starts for City. ‘I have difficulty with headers,’ he laughed. ‘It was a little bit lucky.’

Aguero, whose contract ends in 2021, is not going to be around forever. He visited Argentina during the international break before returning to training — in turn smashing up his car in Hale. Jesus was deemed as having the rhythm to start, a decision that resulted in his 50th goal for the club since joining in 2017.

‘I thought the club bought an incredible young player at an incredible price (£27million from Palmeiras),’ Guardiola said.

The 22-year-old Brazilian striker stooped to head in his 50th goal for Manchester City

‘One of their best signings. Honestly, when he arrived he had an incredible impact. Then he suffered the injuries. Competing with Sergio is maybe the most difficult thing. Sergio is a legend, an outrageous player. Amazing.’

Over the last 12 months, Jesus has been consistently consistent with 26 goals in all competitions.

‘On the pitch, I’m more mature, more experienced, with and without the ball,’ Jesus said. ‘I’m more calm, I understand the game more and I also understand our style of play better. Also, my skills have improved since I arrived. I’m better with my left foot, with headers, with my position on the pitch.

Sergio Aguero is one of just seven strikers in Europe to score at a faster rate than Jesus

‘Off the pitch, I have always been very mature, very responsible. I have grown up as a person. I have always been very attached to my family.’ Attached to the extent that his friends and family failing to renew UK visas coincided with his form dipping last year.

Jesus was away from them for the first time and no amount of help from City could bridge that gap. He is becoming less dependent on them after starting a relationship with Fernanda Queiroz.

‘I’m very happy,’ Jesus said. ‘Last season I had a difficult start to the season. This season is going to be different. I work hard and focus on the goal all the time, and I think that’s why I score a lot.’

Pep Guardiola insists City must become more clinical if they are to win the Champions League

But Guardiola wants more, though. From Jesus and from everyone else. Here came the frank claim that City are not ready to challenge for the Champions League title.

Of 21 shots, only two flew beyond Wayne Hennessey, and the City manager insisted that is not good enough. ‘The people say about the Champions League, that target,’ Guardiola said. ‘We still are not ready. We create a lot, don’t concede, but can improve.

‘But Gabriel’s mentality means he’ll always have success. He is hungry, he wants to become an important striker around the world. We are lucky to have him.’
